schedule.description: Celebrate the 50th anniversary of Apollo 11’s historic mission to the Moon and discover the latest achievements in lunar science.
The annual Powdermill Pollinator Festival is free and open to all, and will include food, garden tours, honey and bee products, as well as a large plant sale.
Let’s go outside! Join other families for an all–ages playground party focused on our colorful play sculpture, Lozziworm.
Are you a Carnegie Museums whiz? Test your knowledge against other power-members in our end-of-the-summer block-party blowout trivia night!
The City of Wilkinsburg takes over Third Thursday with artists and makers who call the neighborhood home.
Grab a friend, get a drink at the cash bar, and enjoy a night out!

Did you know that paleontologists, botanists, zoologists, and many other scientists are making discoveries at the museum? Meet real scientists and learn more about what they do!
Create a toy for your fury friend, something special for your winged wonder or a treat for your scaly pal all while learning more about the pets in our lives!
Take a breezy gallery stroll with one of our expert docents!
Meet the live animals that call Carnegie Museum of Natural History home at Live Animal Encounters.

Gallery talks led by museum staff have a thematic focus around a series of Warhol artworks or one of Warhol’s artistic processes. These 30-minute talks provide time for visitors to present insights and ask questions.
Shows are included with general admission for visitors to the Science Center.

Enjoy a lively, daily conversation with an expert. Discover a new favorite artwork in the permanent collection each week—every tour is unique!

scavengerhunt.clue: Can you locate the first dinosaur discovered by Carnegie paleontologists? You’ll find me there!
scavengerhunt.hint: Look for the dinosaur with the longest tail.
scavengerhunt.answer: Diplodocus carnegii—affectionately known as Dippy—was unearthed in 1899. In fact, the Museum of Natural History was called “the House that Dippy Built.”

scavengerhunt.location: Anzu wyleii - DITT, in the corner near T. rex
scavengerhunt.clue: Now that you’ve met Dippy, I’d like to introduce you to a strange-looking dinosaur that looks like a huge chicken. Can you find it—and me!—hiding in the shadows near the battling T. rex?
scavengerhunt.hint: Look in the corner beyond the triceratops.
scavengerhunt.answer: You found it! This creature, Anzu wyleii, is the first one of its kind. In scientific terms, we call this a holotype. Carnegie paleontologist Matt Lamanna was part of the team that discovered Anzu.

scavengerhunt.location: Pterosaurs - Foster Overlook, outside North American Wildlife
scavengerhunt.clue: I’d like to show you another creature that flies high in the sky in a group. You’ll find me hiding with them!
scavengerhunt.hint: You have to look up! Use the winding stairs or silver elevator located in Dinosaurs in Their Time to go upstairs one level to find me soaring above Diplodocus.
scavengerhunt.answer: Great job! These are pterosaurs. They are not quite dinosaurs, but are very close relatives to them, and are the first vertebrates known to fly. Their fossils are very rare because their bones are brittle and not easily preserved.

scavengerhunt.location: Bird Hall - opposite the Section of Mystery
scavengerhunt.clue: Here’s your next clue: You’ll find me nearby in Bird Hall, hanging out with an ancestor of our feathered friends.
scavengerhunt.hint: Go through the double doors, around the corner, and walk to the top of the ramp and look to your left.
scavengerhunt.answer: Archaeopteryx, discovered in 1860, was once believed to be the earliest known bird. Today, it’s recognized as a significant transitional fossil between dinosaurs and birds.

scavengerhunt.location: Mummy - The child mummy in Egypt
scavengerhunt.clue: The next item is young, but it’s also very, very old. Look for me in Ancient Egypt by a coffin that shines like gold.
scavengerhunt.hint: Head to Walton Hall of Ancient Egypt and look in the room on the very end.
scavengerhunt.answer: Great work! This child mummy was the first item in the collection at the Museum of Natural History.

scavengerhunt.location: John White Alexander - the third floor of the Grand Staircase
scavengerhunt.clue: Can you find the parade on the wall of the third floor balcony? I’m hanging out close by.
scavengerhunt.hint: Look on the wall above the staircase.
scavengerhunt.answer: Great work! This is the top level of John White Alexander’s masterpiece, The Crowning of Labor. Look around at the white walls: Alexander had planned to extend the mural, but unfortunately passed away before his work was complete.

scavengerhunt.location: Dec. Arts - The vitrine located just inside the left-hand set of doors to the Bruce Galleries
scavengerhunt.clue: For your next clue: Shine bright like a diamond—or crystal! Look for me by two dazzling containers in the Bruce Galleries for Decorative Arts and Design on the second floor.
scavengerhunt.hint: The Bruce Galleries are located on the second floor, just off the Grand Staircase.
scavengerhunt.answer: These sparkling decanters were made right here in Pittsburgh for U.S. President James Monroe in 1818. Quite different from our modern water bottles, right?

scavengerhunt.location: Lockheed Lounge - The all-metal Lockheed Lounge
scavengerhunt.clue: It’s a bird, it’s a plane, it’s…a metal couch? Look for this lounge—and me!—just around the corner and decide for yourself.
scavengerhunt.hint: Enter the gallery next to the wall of chairs.
scavengerhunt.answer: Nice work! This sleek lounge made history when it appeared in a Madonna music video in 1993. The designer Marc Newson was an Australian surfer—can you see how this lounge chair is similar to a surfboard?

scavengerhunt.location: The Grand Staircase - The base of the Grand Staircase, next to the steps
scavengerhunt.clue: Don’t stop and “stair’—head to the bottom of this three-story marble beauty. Can you find me hiding near the original front entrance of the museums?
scavengerhunt.hint: Go downstairs to the first floor.
scavengerhunt.answer: You found me! The original entrance of the museum once faced the stairs, awing visitors as they walked in. This Grand Staircase is now considered to be one of the most beautiful museum staircases in the world.

scavengerhunt.clue: Find a place where lions are the king of the desert, not the jungle—can you find me next to this life-and-death battle with a camel and its rider?
scavengerhunt.hint: Look outside of the hall filled with pillars, which is called the Hall of Sculpture.
scavengerhunt.answer: Great work! You found the Lion Attacking a Dromedary, which was displayed at the Paris International Exposition in 1867. This dramatic diorama is a visitor favorite—every time I see it, I wonder: who wins?

trivia-csc.text: What year was the term robot invented?
trivia-csc.followup: It was used in a play entitled R.U.R. by the Czech writer Karel Čapek.

trivia-csc.text: What was a robot like Hoops, the basketball robot, originally used for?
trivia-csc.followup: Hoops nails free-throws with 98% accuracy and has been fascinating Science Center visitors for years.

trivia-csc.text: The digestive system begins in the __________.
trivia-csc.followup: Saliva is important for digestion; humans make about a liter of it each day.

trivia-csc.text: Where else did the Miniature Railroad and Village live before moving to Carnegie Science Center?
trivia-csc.followup: The Miniature Railroad and Village was moved to the Science Center in 1992.

trivia-csc.text: The spectators in the model of Forbes Field are made out of ________?
trivia-csc.followup: The real Forbes Field took only four months to build out of steel and concrete, but the model took over a year to complete.

trivia-csc.text: A good hockey goalie has a reaction time that is ___% faster than an average person’s.
trivia-csc.followup: An average person has a reaction time of about .2 seconds. A hockey goalie is faster at .15 seconds-- those milliseconds count!

trivia-csc.text: _________ is a muscle’s ability to keep up a repeated force.
trivia-csc.followup: Many athletes train for both strength and endurance.

trivia-csc.text: Which of the following materials is used to make athletic tracks?
trivia-csc.followup: Enzymes can transform plant oils into a gel that will harden into a track that you can run on!

trivia-csc.text: The USS Requin saw its first deployment during World War II.
trivia-csc.followup: The USS Requin was never deployed in World War II-the war ended before its assigned deployment date. It was officially deployed in 1949.

trivia-cmnh.text: Luster refers to how a mineral reflects light. Which of the following is NOT a way to describe luster?
trivia-cmnh.followup: Other forms of luster include pearly, dull, waxy, earthy, and silky.

trivia-cmnh.text: The science of rocks is called _____?
trivia-cmnh.followup: Rocks are naturally occuring assemblages of two or more minerals. Rocks constitute an essential part of the Earth’s crust.

trivia-cmnh.text: Early dinosaurs were at the top of the food chain.
trivia-cmnh.followup: Early dinosaurs were generally small and greatly outnumbered by other animals. Toward the end of the Triassic Period, dinosaurs began their rise to dominance.

trivia-cmnh.text: Dinosaurs are closely related to which kind of creature?
trivia-cmnh.followup: Along with crocodiles and pterosaurs (flying reptiles), dinosaurs are members of a reptilian sub-group, archosaurs (ruling reptiles).

trivia-cmnh.text: Stegosaurus had a brain that was the size of  _______________.
trivia-cmnh.followup: Compared to the size of its body (which is comparable to an elephant’s), Stegosaurus had a tiny brain.

trivia-cmnh.text: The growth in popularity of which superfood has had a negative effect on monarch butterfly populations?
trivia-cmnh.followup: Avocado farmers are clearing land, removing a vital buffer of trees that helps stabilize the climate of the butterflies’ winter retreat.
This photo was taken at Powdermill Nature Reserve.
Powdermill Nature Reserve is Carnegie Museum of Natural History’s environmental research facility in Rector, PA.

trivia-cmnh.text: Identify the flower seen in this photograph taken at Powdermill.
trivia-cmnh.followup: To see more great photos, follow Powdermill on Facebook!

trivia-warhol.text: Andy Warhol’s parents were from modern-day
trivia-warhol.followup: Andrej and Julia Warhola were Carpatho-Rusyns who emigrated from what is now eastern Slovakia in the 1920s.

trivia-warhol.text: Warhol attended college at Carnegie Tech (now Carnegie Mellon University). How did he afford it?
trivia-warhol.followup: Warhol’s father Andrej recognized his son’s talent early and saved bonds for his education.
Warhol designed the windows of Joseph Horne’s in downtown Pittsburgh.

trivia-warhol.text: Warhol began his career in New York as a(n) _______.
trivia-warhol.followup: His first commercial work appeared in a 1949 issue of Glamour magazine, in which he illustrated a story called ’What is Success?’

trivia-warhol.text: Just months before he passed in 1987, Warhol contracted his nephew Donald to install a(n) _______.
trivia-warhol.followup: Warhol was ahead of his time, and the computer system was no exception.

trivia-warhol.text: Warhol’s artistic process took off with this technique.
trivia-warhol.followup: This time-saving technique combined drawing with printmaking and allowed Warhol to recreate images quickly, thus outpacing his competition.

trivia-warhol.text: Warhol started experimenting with film in the early 1960s. What is his longest film?
trivia-warhol.followup: The film Empire, showing the Empire State Building, clocks in at 8 hours and 5 minutes.

trivia-warhol.text: Andy Warhol made many artworks around food. Which of the following foods did Andy Warhol claim to eat every day for 20 years?
trivia-warhol.followup: Andy marveled that the soup always tasted the same, whether consumed by prince or pauper.
In the Factory, the walls were painted silver and celebrities streamed in and out.

trivia-cmoa.text: When and where did the art movement known as Impressionism originate?
trivia-cmoa.followup: Impressionism revolutionized attitudes about painting methods, subject matter, and the art market.

trivia-cmoa.text: Impressionist Pierre-Auguste Renoir was included in how many Carnegie Internationals?
trivia-cmoa.followup: The Carnegie International is the longest-running survey of global contemporary art in North America. Many Impressionists were represented in the early years of the Carnegie International.

trivia-cmoa.text: What is the name for the painting technique of using small dots of bright, often contrasting colors, pictured here?
trivia-cmoa.followup: These marks were thought to vibrate or blend in the viewer’s eye to create a more subtle perception.

trivia-cmoa.text: Which painter created this work of art titled ’Wheat Fields after the Rain (The Plain of Auvers)’?
trivia-cmoa.followup: This is one of the very last paintings Vincent van Gogh ever made, painted just days before his death.

trivia-cmoa.text: The Rococo style in decorative arts evolved from the formal, grandiose _________ style.
trivia-cmoa.followup: The Rococo style is characterized by asymmetrical compositions of sensuous S- and C-shaped curves and the use of naturalistic motifs, such as rocks, shells, and foliage.

trivia-cmoa.text: What is the name for the process of returning objects to their original historic form?
trivia-cmoa.followup: The materials used in a restoration are scientifically tested for their stability and reversibility.

trivia-cmoa.text: The Hall of Architecture contains casts of many famous buildings. What material are these copies made of?
trivia-cmoa.followup: Plaster casting allowed masterpieces of sculpture and architecture to be brought to Pittsburgh, for everyone to experience at full scale.

trivia-cmoa.text: This intricate cast comes from the doors on the Cathedral of St. Pierre in France. What are the original doors made of?
trivia-cmoa.followup: Many of the plaster sculptures in the collection have been painted to give a warm, antique appearance that resembles the original building materials.

trivia-cmoa.text: The collection of architectural casts at Carnegie Museum of Art is the largest in the world.
trivia-cmoa.followup: This collection is the third largest in the world, but the largest in the Americas. While most other collections have been either dispersed or destroyed, Carnegie Museum of Art’s collection has endured as an exhibition of world-class significance.
